definition: to be in a bad mood
noisy/cacophonous/to make noise/to disturb/to vent (feelings)/to fall ill/to have an attack (of sickness)/to go in (for some activity)/to joke
feeling/emotion/passion/situation
beginnings/clues/mental state/thread

sentences.english: But I was in a mood, so I made a joke.
sentences.chinese: 但我當時正鬧情緒，所以我開了一個玩笑。

sentences.english: He's in a bad temper today.
There is no time for sentiment.
So your big plans fall through; are you going to go home and sulk?
sentences.chinese: 你的龐大計劃瓦解了，你應該折返回去還是鬧情緒？

sentences.english: I should not like a man who is so soon discomposed by a hot morning.
sentences.chinese: 因爲上午天熱就鬧情緒，我纔不喜歡這樣的人呢。

sentences.english: I never casually mood, because I know no one will coax me.
sentences.chinese: 我從不隨意鬧情緒，因爲深知沒人會哄我。

sentences.english: Play the motions through my head, you know that I'm faking.
sentences.chinese: 你知道我在假裝扮野，在動用腦子鬧情緒。

sentences.english: Be careful you don't flip a switch at that restaurant or even worse do it to your server.
sentences.chinese: 不要在餐館鬧情緒，更不要衝服務員發火。

sentences.english: The best feeling is that you have to adapt to your mood.
sentences.chinese: 最好的感覺莫過於你鬧情緒有人來遷就你。

sentences.english: She remained disgruntled two days later.
sentences.chinese: 兩天過去了，她仍在鬧情緒。

definition: to seethe/to sulk/to be pissed off (vulgar)
to go into a huff
to turn a blind eye
pinyin: zheng1 yi1 zhi1 yan3 bi4 yi1 zhi1 yan3

definition: lit. lotus roots may break, but the fiber remains joined (idiom); lovers part, but still long for one another
to resign oneself to adversity (idiom); to grin and bear it/to submit meekly to insults, maltreatment, humiliation etc
sb who tries to be on good terms with everyone
lit. twice every three days (idiom); practically every day/frequently
docile and obedient/all obedience
hopelessly muddled/impossible to unravel
angry words/sth said in the moment of anger
argumentative/quarrelsome
indecisive/wavering
bad temper
variant of 小題大做|小题大做[xiao3 ti2 da4 zuo4]
Trouble issues from the mouth (idiom). A loose tongue may cause a lot of trouble.
to take one's anger out on sb (who does not deserve it)
